title: An Under-$200 Paint Project Adds Major Drama to This Impeccably Organized Office
description: This maximalist DIYer never thought she'd use white paint, but she made it work with her style. READ MORE...
author: Sarah Everett
excerpt: Even in the most colorful of homes, there’s sometimes a room with white walls to add a bit of balance. In renter Imani Keal’s (@imaniathome) home, that’s the home office. It’s the first room she’s painted white (Sherwin-Williams’ Alabaster).
text: Home ProjectsSarah EverettAssistant Editor of Home ProjectsSarah EverettAssistant Editor of Home ProjectsI organize the Before & After series and cover DIY and design. I joined AT in October 2020 as a production assistant. I have an MA in Journalism from the University of Missouri and a BA in Journalism from Belmont University. Past editorial stops include HGTV Magazine, Nashville Arts Magazine, and local magazines in my hometown, Columbia, Missouri.published nowWe independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.About this before & afterShe describes the white on her home office walls as “white, but not stark” on Instagram, and it’s the perfect backdrop for her home office (which, by the way, still has plenty of color for the polychromatic fans out there). The ceiling, trim, and doors are pink.Imani decided to go bold on the doors and ceiling with pink paint (Valspar’s Frosty Berry.) But before that, she added a bit more architectural drama with rope trim, which Imani cut and nailed about 4 inches below the ceiling. She made sure everything was straight using a laser level. She caulked around the edges, then added her pink paint above it. “This project required no power tools, and each piece of the trim was about $15,” Imani says on Instagram. In total, transforming the room with paint and trim cost less than $200. Wall-to-wall shelving makes the home office more functional. Still, one of her favorite storage items in the room isn’t custom and is a game-changer for renters, she says, and that’s the over-door storage hanger. “I have three over-the-door racks,” Imani tells Apartment Therapy. “My bedroom closet, bathroom, and office all have one, and they’re the perfect storage hack.”Furniture and accessories add more warmth and color. Imani’s shelving units themselves are a neutral color, but her DIY supplies, accessories, and furniture keep this room far from being devoid of color (in addition to the pink paint, of course). “I’m waking up early, going to bed late, spending hours organizing and labeling every inch of this room,” Imani writes on her blog. “And can you blame me?”
html:
• Home Projects

Sarah EverettAssistant Editor of Home Projects

Sarah EverettAssistant Editor of Home Projects

I organize the Before & After series and cover DIY and design. I joined AT in October 2020 as a production assistant. I have an MA in Journalism from the University of Missouri and a BA in Journalism from Belmont University. Past editorial stops include HGTV Magazine, Nashville Arts Magazine, and local magazines in my hometown, Columbia, Missouri.

published now

We independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.

About this before & after

She describes the white on her home office walls as “white, but not stark” on Instagram, and it’s the perfect backdrop for her home office (which, by the way, still has plenty of color for the polychromatic fans out there). 

The ceiling, trim, and doors are pink.

Imani decided to go bold on the doors and ceiling with pink paint (Valspar’s Frosty Berry.) But before that, she added a bit more architectural drama with rope trim, which Imani cut and nailed about 4 inches below the ceiling. She made sure everything was straight using a laser level. She caulked around the edges, then added her pink paint above it. 

“This project required no power tools, and each piece of the trim was about $15,” Imani says on Instagram. In total, transforming the room with paint and trim cost less than $200. 

Wall-to-wall shelving makes the home office more functional. 

Still, one of her favorite storage items in the room isn’t custom and is a game-changer for renters, she says, and that’s the over-door storage hanger. “I have three over-the-door racks,” Imani tells Apartment Therapy. “My bedroom closet, bathroom, and office all have one, and they’re the perfect storage hack.”

Furniture and accessories add more warmth and color. 

Imani’s shelving units themselves are a neutral color, but her DIY supplies, accessories, and furniture keep this room far from being devoid of color (in addition to the pink paint, of course). 

“I’m waking up early, going to bed late, spending hours organizing and labeling every inch of this room,” Imani writes on her blog. “And can you blame me?”
